Recorded Sayings of Chan Master Wubian of Dongshan. The master, when young, followed a teacher. While reciting the Diamond Sutra, he came to the line no eyes, ears, nose, tongue,
body, or mind.
He then covered his face with his hands
and asked the teacher, saying,
I have eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and so forth.
Why does the sutra say 'no'?
His teacher was startled and said,
I am not your teacher.
He then pointed him to go to Mount Wufeng to pay respects to Chan Master Lingmo.
The master traveled to various places and first visited Nanyue.
He arrived on the day of Mazu's death anniversary when a vegetarian feast was being held.
Nanyue asked the assembly, saying,
Tomorrow we will prepare a vegetarian feast for Mazu.
Will Mazu come or not?
The entire assembly had no response.
The master then came forward and said,
Only if there is a companion will I come.
Nanyue said,
Although this child is young,
he is very suitable for carving.
The master said,
Master, please do not despise good for bad.
The master visited Nanyue.
He asked:
I have heard about the teaching of insentient beings by National Teacher Zhong of Nanyang.
I have not yet understood its subtlety.

Do you remember it?
The master said: I remember it.

You try to recite it once.

A monk asked:
What is the mind of the ancient buddhas?
The national teacher said:
Walls, tiles, and pebbles are.
The monk said:
Aren't walls, tiles, and pebbles insentient?
The national teacher said: Yes.
The monk said:
Do they understand the teaching?
The national teacher said:
They always speak, speaking ardently,

The monk said:

The national teacher said:
You yourself do not hear it.
It cannot hinder those who do hear it.
The monk said:
I do not know.
Who can hear it?
The national teacher said:

The monk said,
Master, do you hear it or not?
The National Teacher said,
I do not hear it.
The monk said,
Since the master does not hear it,
how can you know that insentient beings expound the Dharma?
The National Teacher said,
I am fortunate not to hear it.
If I heard it, I would be equal to the sages.
You would not hear me expound the Dharma.
The monk said,
In that case, sentient beings have no share.
The National Teacher said,
I expound it for sentient beings,
not for the sages.
The monk said,
What will happen to sentient beings after they hear it?
The National Teacher said,
They are not sentient beings.
The monk said,
The insentient expounding the Dharma - what canon is this based on?
The National Teacher said,
Indeed.
Words that do not encompass the canon are not what gentlemen discuss.
How could you not see?
The Huayan Sutra says,
The lands expound, sentient beings expound, and everything in the three times expounds.
The master finished reciting.
Mount Xuedou said,
